vernacular and the most widely spoken and understood colloquial variety of Arabic. It is spoken by more than 90 million people, mainly in Egypt. It is used in everyday speech, comics, advertising, song lyrics, teen magazines, plays, and TV shows, but rarely in novels, newspapers, and never in news reporting, which use

instead.

The phrasebook is based on the metropolitan Egyptian Arabic based on the pronunciation of urban Egyptians in
Arabic alphabet in general differ in shape slightly, depending on their position in the word.

Egyptian Arabic has more vowels than the three of Classical Arabic, and it differentiates between short and long vowels. Long vowels are shown in this phrasebook with a macron or a circumflex above the vowel.

The stress falls on the syllable with a long vowel and/or the next-to-last syllable. Stress isn't marked in words without a long vowel for simplification. Words can't have more than one long vowel. Long vowels can't occur before two consonants.

The following are a little more unusual:

; D

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', KacstOne, sans-serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

pronounced with the tongue raised and mouth tensed. Most Egyptians don't distinguish its pronunciation from

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', KacstOne, sans-serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

pronounced with the tongue raised and mouth tensed. Not pronounced in all positions.
; T

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', KacstOne, sans-serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

pronounced with the tongue raised and mouth tensed. Not pronounced in all positions.
; x

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', KacstOne, sans-serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

(xà): a harsh sound found in rare English words like

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', KacstOne, sans-serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

pronounced with the tongue raised and mouth tensed. Not pronounced in all positions.
; q

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', KacstOne, sans-serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

pronounced in the back of the mouth
. In Egyptian Arabic it is usually a glottal stop

.

The last two are hard for non-native speakers, so try to get a native speaker to demonstrate. That said, most beginners tend to opt for the simple approach of ignoring those pesky apostrophes entirely, but it's worth it to make the effort.

; <font size=4> ’ </font>

value: ء أ إ آ ؤ ئ

, or the constriction of the throat as between the syllables

, but in Arabic this is often found in strange places such as the end of a word.

; <font size=5> ` </font>

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', KacstOne, sans-serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

, famously equated to the sound of someone being strangled.

: asaseyyāt أساسيات

Many Arabic expressions are slightly different for men and women, depending both on the gender of the person talking (you) and the person being addressed.

el xēr مساء الخير

value: |- style="font-size:350%; font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; line-height:normal"
backup image if numerals don't display

Formally called "Eastern Arabic Numerals". In Arabic, known as "Indian numbers" (أرقام هندية àrqâm hendeyya). Be careful that the zero is represented as a dot (

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal
font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

) looks like the familiar zero. Furthermore, numbers are read left-to-right and

right-to-left as for Arabic text. Decimals are separated by the Latin-based comma, as the case with central European languages, not with a dot as the case for English language. The Latin-based comma looks different from the Arabic comma (

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

) or a similar mark which divides long numbers.

Also note that the numeral three (

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

a handwriting (with a single wide hook) may appear like the numeral two (

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal

) in print (with a single narrow hook).

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal;line-height:1

): wāHed واحد   —   first: awwal أول   —   the first (definitive f.): el ūla الأولى

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal;line-height:1

): etnēn إتنين   —   second: tāni تانى   —   second (definitive f.): et-tanya التانية

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal;line-height:1

): talāta تلاتة   —   third: tālet تالت   —   third (definitive f.): et-talta التالتة

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal;line-height:1

): xamsa خمسة   —   fifth: xāmes خامس   —   fifth (definitive f.): el xamsa الخامسة

value.style: font-size:200%;font-family:'Times New Roman', 'Arabic Transparent', Arial, 'Simplified Arabic', Scheherazade, Lateef, 'Arabic Typesetting', serif; position: relative; top: 0.05em;font-weight:normal;line-height:1

): setta ستة   —   sixth: sādes سادس   —   sixth (definitive f.): es-sadsa السادسة

fâSel setta talāta ألف فاصل ستة تلاتة
1) First man, first woman. أول راجل, أول ست awwal rāgel, awwal sett
The first man, the first woman. الراجل الأول الست الأولى er-rāgel el awwal, es-sett el ūla
2) Second man, second woman. تانى راجل, تانى ست tāni rāgel, tāni sett
The second man, the second woman. الراجل التانى, الست التانية er-rāgel et-tāni, es-sett et-tanya
3) Third man, third woman. تالت راجل, تالت ست tālet rāgel, tālet sett
The third man, the third woman. الراجل التالت, الست التالتة er-rāgel et-tālet, es-sett et-talta
